chapter.para: Steps perform units of work. How those steps are connected together determines the overall result of a pipeline. As we said in , connections in XProc are always written from the perspective of the step with the input port.
Inputs can be connected, or “bound”, in four different ways. An input can be connected to:

listitem.para: A document identified by a URI. “Read from http://example.com/document.xml.”
An output port on another step in the pipeline. “Read the output of the result port on that p:xslt step.”
A literal document specified inline in the pipeline. “Take this XML from the pipeline, create a document out of it, and use it as the input.”

chapter.para: If an input port accepts a sequence of documents, then more than one input binding can be specified and the various kinds of connections can be mixed arbitrarily.

If an input port has no explicit connections, then it will automatically be connected to the default readable port, if there is one. It's an error to leave an input port unconnected, so if there is neither an explicit connection nor a default readable port, the pipeline is not valid.

section.title: Input Connections
section.para: The most common kind of input is a p:input, an input to an atomic step, but several other kinds of inputs exist. Each is conceptually an input, but they were given their own names because they exhibit some differences from a standard input:

listitem.para: p:iteration-source on p:for-each. The p:for-each has only a single input and it doesn't have a name. It functions as the input to the p:for-each step.
p:viewport-source on p:viewport. Like p:for-each, the p:viewport has only a single input and it doesn't have a name. It functions as the input to the p:viewport step.

p:xpath-context on p:choose and p:when. The XPath context in a p:choose is also an input. It has no name and special defaulting rules apply. It establishes the document that is the context node for evaluating the test expressions.

p:variable in a compound step. The value of a variable is determined by evaluating an XPath expression; the binding for that p:variable establishes the document that is the context node for the expression.

p:with-option and p:with-param on steps. Like variables, the values of options and parameters are determined by evaluating an XPath expression; the bindings for them establish the document that is the context node for their expressions.

section.para: You can think of each of these items as being “bindable”, capable of having a document (or documents) bound to them. As we'll see in , all of these bindings may be relevant in determining the order in which steps are evaluated.

section.title: Selecting parts of a document
section.para: Ordinary p:input connections and p:iteration-source inputs can include a select expression. If a select expression is specified, then all of the elements in each input document that match the specified expression are used as the input. In this case, each matching node is converted into a document in its own right and the parts of the document that did not match the select expression are effectively ignored.

It's important to remember that the input to a step is a document or a sequence of documents. When a select expression is used, all the elements selected are effectively extracted from their original documents and turned into documents in their own right. (This may have an impact on ID/IDREF links, if there are any.)
Consider the following input statement:

What this input does is provide, for the step on which it occurs, a sequence of documents on the “source” input port. That sequence of documents consists of the single XHTML document identified by the URI “homepage.xhtm”. (In this and many other cases, the sequence will be exactly one document, but that is not necessarily the case for a p:input.)
In contrast, consider this input statement:

This input provides a sequence of documents on the “source” input port as well. In this case, that sequence consists of one document for every top level h:div that occurs in the document identified by the URI “homepage.xhtm”.

(If the select expression had been instead “//h:div”, then there would have been one document for every h:div in the document. In the case of nested divisions, this would have resulted in (copies of) the same nodes appearing in more than one document.)

When you use a select expression, you may change the number of documents that appear on the port. You can reduce a sequence of documents to a single document, or produce a sequence of documents from a single document. The step on which the input occurs will only know about the result after applying the select expression. This means, for example, that you could send 1,000 documents to an input that didn't accept a sequence if you also provided a select expression that would select only a single element from all those documents.

section.title: Dependencies and the Order of Execution
section.para: Most of the pipelines you write will probably be pretty straightforward. Even as your experience with XProc grows and you tackle more and more complex problems with it, you're not likely to write pipelines that are intentionally obfuscated: if step “A” produces output that step “B” consumes, you'll probably put the “A” step before the “B” step in your pipeline document.
You'll probably take advantage of the default readable port to simplify your pipelines. This will naturally lead to a “top to bottom” flow in your pipelines.
Unfortunately, a pipeline processor can't rely on the organization that you'll probably use. The processor has to analyze your pipeline and determine a specific order in which to run the steps.
The processor uses two rules to determine the order in which to run steps:

listitem.para: Any step “Y” that consumes the output of another step “X” (i.e., has an input binding to some output port of “X”) must run after step “X”.
It is an error if any step consumes its own output, either directly or indirectly.

section.para: The second rule means that you can't form a loop of dependencies. Such a pipeline isn't valid and can't be run. In the terms of our “flowing water” analogy, this is the equivalent of connecting the output of some box to the input of some box that's “above” it. Water just doesn't flow that way.
If there are no loops in a pipeline, then there is at least one way to arrange all the steps pipeline such that every step is run after every step on which it depends.
Technically, this is a partial order. Consider the pipeline in .

If we enforce the constraint that every step must run after every step that it depends on, one possible way to run this pipeline is to run the steps in this order: A, B, C, D, E, F. But that constraint is equally satisfied by this order: A, D, B, C, E, F. Or A, B, D, E, C, F.
The situation is even more obvious in .
Here we have a pipeline with four steps, but the A/B and C/D pipelines are entirely independent. Any order that preserves the constraint that B runs after A and D runs after C is acceptable.
The point I'm trying to make is that you can't rely on a processor running steps in any order that isn't determined by the connections between the steps.

tip.para: XML Calabash has an extension attribute that allows you to assert additional dependencies. You can use the attribute cx:depends-on on any step. The value of the attribute is the name of a step that you want to make sure the processor runs before it runs the step on which you've placed the extension attribute.
